Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: The Justice Department announced a consent decree with Norwegian Cruise Line to resolve a lawsuit under the Americans with Disabilities Act on behalf of individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing, and individuals who use wheelchairs, who took NCL cruises of the Hawaiian Islands.

Norwegian Cruise Line Ltd. signed a plea agreement with the United States acknowledging a felony violation of the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships and further agreeing to pay a $1 million criminal fine after turning itself in and cooperating with prosecutors.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Norwegian Cruise Lines agreed to pay $526,602 in back wages to 2,059 employees following an investigation by the U.S. Department of Labor's Wage and Hour Division that disclosed systemic violations of the federal Fair Labor Standards Act's minimum wage, overtime and record-keeping provisions for employees of the company's Pride of America cruise ship in Hawaii.
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: Norwegian Cruise Line was fined $55,000 for violating a state environmental law requiring that ships keep emissions from reducing visibility through their exhaust plume by more than 20% while in Alaska waters.
The company was fined $1 million and ordered to pay $13.75 million in restitution to victims of a 2003 boiler explosion in the Port of Miami.
Info Source: NORWEGIAN CRUISE LINE CONVICTED AND SENTENCED FOR GROSS CRIMINAL NEGLIGENCE IN 2003 INCIDENT, US Fed News, May 21, 2008 (via Nexis).

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 713990: All Other Amusement and Recreation Industries
Info Source: February 7, 2020 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Robocall violations. The total settlement agreed to by Carnival Corp, Norwegian Cruise Line and Royal Caribbean Cruises was $12.5 million. The settlement did not specify how much each would pay. Here we assume each paid one-third.
Private Litigation Case Title: Charvat v. Travel Services et al
